title: If we're giving assassins new items and reworks, why not Trickster's Glass
body:
Trickster's Glass could be perfect for an assassin.  It lets you disguise yourself as a less threatening character on your team so its more possible to get your burst off and it even has a blink built into it if you want to use it for pure mobility.  Just gear the stats to an assassin and it should work.

Also Trickster's Glass is the most fun item ever.

While I don't think Trickster's Glass is specifically needed, there do need to be more AP items that are for Assassins. Right now we have... Lich Bane? Protobelt, which wasn't meant for assassins? Luden's, which is better on traditional mages? Gunblade counts I guess, but thats severly limited by also having AD.

The lack of distinctly assassin items in the AP space is a huge oversight for this update, especially since there are big changes to AD assassin items to make them more distinctly assassin.

There is 1 big issue with AP assassins items - it will turn mages into assassins. Mages like AP, mages like CDR and why wouldn't mages like that additional burst that turns them into sub assassins? Remember old Ahri? Yeah. Waveclear assassins with a huge range aren't so great.

Of course, the same is sort of true with AD assassins and marksmen. But marksmen usually want some AS and Crit aswell, so they are not that satisfied with Raw AD and CDR. But {{item:3147}} is still a problem on some ADCs as it gives ARpen instead of CDR and thus fits marksmen quite well.

It won't turn any mage into an assassin any more than they already are an assassin. If a burst mage is too powerful with an item designed specifically for assassins, then they probably need their burst or their mobility toned down.

(I'd argue that Ahri is still and has always been an assassin but that's a discussion for another thread)

AP Assassin items wouldn't need to be high AP items with CDR. In fact, CDR shouldn't be needed for AP assassin items because they will generally want to kill a target in a single rotation. Much like the AD Assassin itemization on PBE, AP assassin itemization can be well defined by specializing in roaming power (out of combat movement speed) and flat penetration (which, while still beneficial to regular mages, is more useful to a champion with good target selection i.e. an assassin), as well as providing passive and/or active effects that are good for roaming and assassination, like Edge of Night and the new Duskblade do for AD assassins.

Items that fit these conditions wouldn't be attractive to Mages unless they already have very assassin-like patterns (see: Ahri, TF, Liss)

While Lich Bane's mana and CDR aren't representative of the direction AP assassin itemization should go, its other benefits are: movement speed, a moderate amount of AP - enough to make it worth an item slot but not enough to replace more core mage items, and a passive that uniquely benefits patterns already typical of AP assassins (given that on the whole an AP assassin is much more likely to incorporate an autoattack into a combo, see: Ekko, Fizz, Akali)

No matter what anyone says, Ahri is just as much of as an assassin as Fizz is.

High mobility? Check.
High burst? Check.
Short term single target CC to keep a target locked down? Check.

Sounds like someone made for hunting down a single target and then GTFO...like an assassin.

Great waveclear? Check.
High range? Check.
Safe? Check.
CC? Check.

Sounds like someone made for clearing waves while being safe and providing utility for the team. Ahri does not have quite enough burst to qualify for being an assassin after the E changes and the removal of DFG. She is most definetely a mage. "Assassin" is her secondary, however she is far away from being a proper assassin - or maybe just one AP assassin item away ;)

She shouldn't be an assassin as she clearly lacks the risk when going in and falling behind. Assassins should not be able to safely farm from range (inb4 Zed - yes he is _very_ safe in terms of farming, but his all in is surely more risky than Ahri's) and stay at range even when all-inning. 
That is why Ahri and the like should not have access to DFG. They would go from dealing decent damage and providing waveclear and utility for their team to doing all that AND instagibbing the enemy ADC way too easily.

Her waveclear is average, and the most successful lane assassins have comparable if slightly worse waveclear (see: Zed, Talon, Leblanc, lane Kha when W evolve annihilated waves)
She has range on her Q and E but in order to do meaningful damage she has to get close - W and R have short ranges and prioritize the nearest targets
Her safety in lane isn't unique for an assassin (see: Zed, Leblanc)
her CC is a single target pick spell that's ideal for an assassin

Ahri doesn't "sit back and clear waves and provide utility" - she has next to no utility to provide in comparison to a burst mage (who often bring reliable AoE hard CC as well as some other form of CC)

Her job is to:
a) burst a squishy if she can (which she can do because with her ultimate and E she has the mobility and target selection of an assassin) 
or b) damage whatever target is nearest to her without dying (which is the fallback pattern of any assassin who can't successfully dive for a kill)

Because of that play pattern, because her damage is primarily single target, and because she has mobility and pick potential, she is very much more an Assassin than she is a Mage

--------

Moving on from the topic of Ahri,

DFG was a bad item. Everyone recognizes it was a bad item. If you think DFG is what people want when they say "I want an AP Assassin item!" you're wrong. People aren't that dumb. I was originally going to post something very long winded about how AP Assassin items could work and why you shouldn't be afraid of Mages picking up assassin items, but for now I'll leave you with this: The only "AP Assassin item" that could "turn mages into assassins" as you say was DFG, which was a terribly designed item. It provided maximum AP, CDR, and a generally useful active. Its the exact opposite of what anyone should want from an AP assassin item.

She is more focused on kiting somebody to death than outright bursting them down.

>DFG was a bad item. Everyone recognizes it was a bad item.

I wholeheartedly disagree with this entire statement. I think the item was mostly fine as it was only used on champions with a lot of single target burst, and it was used as a tool to snowball. The only champions that bought it that Riot didn't anticipate/want to were Syndra and Veigar. Rather than making efforts to change the numbers on the active they took the lazy option and removed it. Frankly the item could easily be put back in the game, but replace the 15% max health nuke with a ~250 damage (base damage of gunblade active) nuke.

TF, Ahri and Liss certainly have 0 problem incorporating an extra autoattack.

There's always going to be some class overlap in terms of who picks up items, but that shouldn't be an excuse to not make items in service to established classes that are in need of some love. There's also no reason that characters who are arguably assassins (Ahri) or who are on the border between mage and assassin (TF, to a much lesser extent Liss) shouldn't also be able to buy these items and benefit from them. If those champions become too strong because of those items (and I know that Ahri is strong right now already), then its on them, not on the items! Ezreal shouldn't be a reason to keep items like Iceborn Gauntlet out of the hands of bruisers and tanks who really benefit from it!

If you had, say, a direct AP version of Edge of Night (80-90 AP instead of 60 AD, 10-15 flat mpen instead of Lethality), whose to say Ahri or TF or Lissandra or another heavy roamer like Taliyah shouldn't be able to use it? By buying that item, they are intentionally choosing to accentuate their roaming and burst strengths instead of boosting their sustained damage or ability to waveclear. Isn't that what items are all about? Choosing which of your strengths to play up and which of your weaknesses to dim?

The passive 'breaks' some of the rules and expectations we have about the game. Sure it would be something really fun for the people who can do this, it would be pretty shitty for those playing against it though. It's a really game warping item in terms of playings decision tree. It's no longer 'I see lux bottom we can can do X'. You don't _know_ it's Lux and that widens the decision tree substantially. How you react is normally contingent on the information of who is where. By introducing dis-information they can't react in the same way. It becomes a game of trying to play each others minds (like poker). Is it lux or is it not lux?- do you want to call the bluff?
